__data__.text:
- Claude List was born in Maryborough, Queensland, Australia on December 2, 1902.
- His parents were Heinrich (Henry) Wilschefski and Mary Frances Carter.
- Henry was born in Germany and Mary in Gorton, Lancashire, England.
- They married in 1897 and had three children: Percy Lawrence Wilschefski (1899-1964), Annie Evelyn Wilschefski (1900-1982), and Claude.
- Henry died in Queensland on November 14, 1903, when Claude was just 11 months old.
- In 1907, Mary remarried to Francis Martin List who had also been born in Germany.
- They had 5 children, making them Claude's half-siblings: Norman Andrew List (1908-1908), Alice Holly List (1909-1995), Francis Martin List (1911-1976), Edna Marjorie List (1913-1914), and Irene Maude List (1915-?).
- Sometime between October 1915 and 1919, the family moved to New Zealand and lived in Glen Eden in 1919.
- Francis was a senior rugby league player and played with Claude on occasion.
- Claude started playing rugby league in Queensland as a schoolboy at about the age of 10 in 1912.
- After moving to New Zealand, he settled in Auckland and played for Kingsland Rovers.
- He made his debut for Kingsland's third grade side on June 10, 1921, at the age of 18.
- His Kingsland side won the 3rd grade championship in 1921.
- In 1922, he continued to play for their 3rd grade side who were runners up in the championship.
- By 1923, Claude had moved into the Kingsland 2nd grade side.
- In 1924, he was still in the 2nd grade side and was playing on the wing.
- His Kingsland side won the 2nd grade

- He scored 3 tries in a 21–3 win for Kingsland in round 2
- Scored 3 more tries in their 13 all draw with Māngere United in round 3
- Made several breaks but was pulled up by smart tackling in a 16–3 loss to Otahuhu Rovers
- Scored another try in a 8–5 loss to Northcote
- Said to be responsible for several particularly fine solo efforts in a 9–5 loss to Ellerslie United
- Described as a clever player who usually scores the most number of points for his side
- Selected in the three quarters of the B team by selectors Edward Fox, Albert Asher, and Ronald McDonald for an Auckland trial side
- Played well in a 5–0 win to his side, saving tries and making breaks
- Described as a fine wing-three quarter with a good turn of speed and the best of the B team’s backs
- Named as a reserve for the Auckland side to play New Zealand but did not take the field
- Named as an emergency player for Auckland's match with South Auckland (Waikato) on August 19
- Selected in the Auckland touring side, stated to be 22 years old and weighing 12 stone
- Scored a try for Auckland B in their 22 to 15 win over West Coast
- Named in the match against Canterbury, but did not feature prominently in the match reports
- Chosen again for their final tour match against Wellington, scoring a try in the 68 points to 9 thrashing
- Combined with Ben Davidson to put Davidson in for a try in the Wellington match
- Scored 2 tries in a 36–19 win for Auckland over South Auckland in his full Auckland debut
- Described as essaying a side dash down the line but being well grassed by Smith when near the corner flag in his Auckland debut.

- Auckland played against a local side at Newtown Park in Wellington, winning the match with a score of 68-9.
- List scored a try in the match, which helped increase Auckland’s lead to 23-4.
- List was chosen in the full Auckland side to play against South Auckland on September 19.
- In his debut, he scored 2 tries in a 36-19 win at Carlaw Park.
- List played on the wing with Ben Davidson at center, and Leonard Riley and Hector Cole in the five-eighth positions.
- He scored a try in the first half and was involved in another try scored by Arthur Singe.
- In the second half, List scored another try and was involved in a try scored by Davidson.
- The Auckland Star praised List’s performance, while the Herald noted that he started poorly but improved in the second half.
- List was chosen as a reserve for the Auckland Province match against the touring Queensland side on October 10.
- However, he was not given a chance to play in the match, and the Herald criticized the selectors for their decision.
- In the 1926 season, List played 16 matches for Kingsland and scored 11 tries, making him their equal leading try-scorer.
- He made 4 appearances for Auckland and scored 7 tries, again making him one of their leading try-scorers.
- List also played in a New Zealand trial match and scored a try.
- At the start of the year, he was elected on to the Kingsland club committee.
- In their first game of the season against Otahuhu, List scored all Kingsland's points with a try and a conversion in a 6-5 loss.
- He scored further tries in a round 3 loss to Northcote and a round 5 win over Parnell.
- List was then named as a reserve for a New Zealand trial match at Carlaw Park.
- He was chosen in a B Team trial side to play on July 10 and scored one of their tries.
- The Auckland Star praised List’s performance, noting that he was one of their best three-quarters.

(298 words)

- The passage discusses the rugby career of a player named List in 1924.
- He played in a curtain-raiser for the North Island v South Island clash, and was chosen for a B Team trial side.
- List scored a try in the B Team's 30-28 win and was considered one of their outstanding backs.
- He missed selection for the New Zealand touring side, but was selected for the Auckland side to play the New Zealand team before they left.
- List scored a try in Auckland's 52-32 win and was praised for his performance.
- The New Zealand selectors were criticized for not selecting List, along with Ivan Littlewood and Hickey, for the tour.
- List was then selected for the Auckland squad to play Otago and scored a try in their 14-4 win.
- He scored 4 tries in a 24-0 win for Kingsland over Otahuhu Rovers and 2 tries in a 21-8 win over Māngere United.
- List was named in the Auckland squad to play Canterbury and scored a try in their 33-15 win.
- He threw the final pass for Maurice Wetherill's try and set up another for George Wade.
- List was praised for his straight running and strong fending in the match.
- He returned to the Kingsland side for their match with Northcote, who were leading the B Division competition with 2 matches remaining.

- Early in a match, List accelerated the pace of the movement after receiving a pass from Prentice, scoring a try while being closely guarded by Canterbury backs.
- Later in the same match, List had a great race for possession with a player from the opposing team, winning by a touch.
- The Herald praised List's performance, noting his straight running and strong fending, and suggested that he could develop into a brilliant attacking center three-quarter if he cooperated more with the wings.
- List played for the Kingsland side against Northcote, which helped them secure the runner-up position in the B Division competition.
- The Herald recognized List's talent and believed that other players of equal merit were waiting for their chance in the B section teams.
- List was chosen for the Auckland side to play against the South Auckland side from the Waikato, scoring 3 tries in Auckland's victory.
- His performance in the match was impressive, with the Herald praising his straight running and contribution to the team's collaborative efforts.
- List played a crucial role in Kingsland's Stallard Cup knockout final win against Parnell, setting up a try for Carter and scoring one himself.
- In 1927, List played 13 matches for Kingsland Rovers and 5 games for Auckland, scoring the most tries for the representative side.
- He also made his debut appearance for the North Island representative side.
- List's season started early, being selected for the Auckland side to play the returning Auckland members of the New Zealand team from their England and Wales tour.
- He scored a try in the match and was praised for his sharp burst of speed, straight running, and delightful swerving.
- List played 13 games for Kingsland from May 14 to September 3, with his performance against Otahuhu on July 9 being particularly noteworthy.
- His younger brother, Francis, also played in the Kingsland side with him in a match against Mangere on May 28.
- The Auckland Star praised List's performance in the Otahuhu match, noting his consistent presence and solid defensive work.

- Auckland club rugby player, List, played 13 games for Kingsland from May 14 to September 3.
- Noted for his "straight running and delightful swerving", he was a strong contender for the center three-quarter position in the rep. team.
- His brother, Francis, also played in the same Kingsland team.
- List was praised for his performance in the match against Mangere on May 28, with the Auckland Star calling him "the best of the backs".
- He scored Kingsland's only points in their final match against Ellerslie United on August 13, which they lost 9-3.
- The Auckland Star suggested that List and Littlewood, of Ellerslie, were strong contenders for the last New Zealand team that toured England.
- List was named in an 18-player squad to tour south for Auckland and played in the first match of the tour against Canterbury at Monica Park in Christchurch.
- He scored a try in the match, with the Christchurch Press praising his "determined running" and ability to "get past tacklers".
- List was then named in the reserves for the match against Otago and did not play in the final match of the tour against Wellington.
- He was selected to play in his first ever match for the North Island side to play the South Island, scoring a try in the match.
- List was praised for his defensive play, with the Auckland Star calling him "the better type of centre, straight running, unselfish, and clever at catering for his wings."

- "List" is a notable football player.
- He played on the wing in a match at Carlaw Park, where the North Island won against the South Island with a score of 13-8. List scored a try in the first half.
- On October 8, List played in the Auckland side against Buller, scoring 3 tries in an easy 60-33 victory.
- In the final match of the season against South Auckland, List scored a try, but Auckland lost the game.
- List was considered one of the best Auckland backs, with the Auckland Star praising his all-round play.
- In 1928, List played for Kingsland in the B Division. He was in good form and was expected to do well against the English team.
- He played as a center three-quarter and scored 2 tries in Auckland's 22-3 win against South Auckland.
- List's strong running and ability to gather bad passes were noted by the Herald.
- He was a tower of strength for Kingsland in their 19-10 win against Parnell.
- Despite an injury, List played well in Kingsland's 8-3 victory over Otahuhu.
- List was chosen as one of the two best center three-quarters for the Auckland team.
- There was little coverage of Kingsland's matches, and it is unknown if List scored any tries for them.

- He originally was chosen to play on the wing with Len Scott, but was moved to center with Roy Hardgrave on the wings for his debut match.
- He scored 2 tries in their 22-3 win at Carlaw Park.
- His first try was after the entire back line had handled the ball, except for Scott, and List went in for a try.
- His second try was after "pretty in and out passing by the backs and forwards" and was described as the best try of the game.
- The Herald said he was a player who caught the eye and played center three-quarter.
- He returned to the Kingsland side and scored a try in their 6 points to 3 win against Mangere.
- Against Grafton, he made some clever openings and was the best back on the ground in their 8-3 loss.
- He was then selected in an Auckland Possibles side to play in an Auckland trial.
- His Possibles side won 24-14 and he scored a try in the win.
- He was selected to play for Auckland against Canterbury on July 21 at Carlaw Park and scored twice in Auckland's 66 to 26 win.
- He was then selected to play for Auckland against South Auckland on July 25 at center and scored a try in Auckland's 19-17 loss.
- He was named as an emergency for the North Island side to play the South Island on July 28.
- He was named on the wing for the Possibles in the New Zealand trial match to be played midweek on August 1.
- List's Possibles side lost 27-24.
- He was chosen by Edward Fox, W.J. Mitchell, and W Murray, for the New Zealand side to make his national debut in the first test against England on August 4 at Carlaw Park.
- He thus became the first ever player to gain selection for New Zealand whilst playing for a second division club.

- In a match between Auckland and another team, List scored a try but was criticized for passing infield to Dixon instead of to an unmarked Scott.
- List was only named as an emergency for the North Island side to play the South Island on July 28.
- He was named on the wing for the Possibles in the New Zealand trial match on August 1, which they lost 27-24.
- List scored a try in the first half of the trial match.
- He was chosen by Edward Fox, W.J. Mitchell, and W Murray, for the New Zealand side to make his national debut in the first test against England on August 4 at Carlaw Park.
- List became the first ever player to gain selection for New Zealand whilst playing for a second division club.
- He was named in the centres with Roy Hardgrave and Len Scott on the wings, Craddock Dufty at fullback, and Maurice Wetherill and Stan Prentice in the five eighth positions, and Frank Delgrosso at halfback.
- New Zealand won the match 17-13 causing a great upset in front of a crowd estimated at well over 20,000.
- List scored a try in the win.
- List was then selected for the Auckland Provincial side to play England 4 days later.
- He was in the centres, opposite Mel Rosser.
- The Auckland Provincial side lost to England 14–9 in front of 15,000 spectators.
- List was then chosen for the Auckland side to play England on August 11.
- Auckland lost the match 26–15 with 25,000 in attendance at Carlaw Park.
- List played opposite Jim Brough and Les Fairclough on the English side.
- Early in the match, List was involved in a try scored by Len Scott.
- Later, List intercepted a pass and cleared when England were attacking through Bryn Evans, Billo Rees, and Brough.
- List was named as part of a larger three quarter group to play in the second test with one to be omitted. The players were Len Scott, Hec Brisbane, List, and Roy Hardgrave.

- Auckland team in a match against England was similar to the test team, with 12 of the 13 players being New Zealand representatives.
- List, one of the players, played opposite Jim Brough and Les Fairclough on the English side.
- List scored a try early in the match by passing to Hardgrave after receiving the ball from Delgrosso.
- Later, List intercepted a pass and cleared when England was attacking through Bryn Evans, Billo Rees, and Brough.
- List was named in a larger three-quarter group for the second test, but he was ultimately not selected.
- He was also bracketed for the 3rd test but did not make the side.
- It is probable that List had an injury, which was the reason for his non-selection.
- On September 8, List played for Kingsland against Otahuhu, but he was not in a fit condition due to an injured leg.
- The match was called off by the referee at halftime due to the behavior of the Otahuhu players and spectators.
- List had recovered enough to be named in the Auckland squad against Otago on September 15, and he played in the match.
- Auckland won the match 42-22, and List was involved in two of their tries.
- His final game for Kingsland was in their Stallard Cup semi-final 18-10 defeat to Grafton Athletic on September 22.
- List was selected in the Auckland side to play North Auckland (Northland) on October 6 in Whangārei.
- At the start of the 1929 season, List's Kingsland Rovers club merged with Grafton Athletic to be admitted into the first grade competition.
- List played 15 matches for Kingsland and scored 7 tries and kicked a drop goal.
- He also played 3 matches for Auckland, scoring 2 tries.
- List scored a try in a practice match against Northcote on April 20 before Kingsland's opening match in first grade against City Rovers at Carlaw Park on April 27.
- Kingsland lost the match 21-6 with List scoring one of their two tries.
- Against

- April 20: Scored a try in a practice match against Northcote
- April 27: Scored one of Kingsland's two tries in a 21-6 loss to City Rovers
	+ Criticized for passing wildly at times
- May 4: Received the ball only on rare occasions against Devonport, but gave a great defensive display in a 29-7 loss

	+ Set up R. Carter for a try in a 12-10 loss to Newton
	+ Played well in the match

	+ Best of Kingsland's backs along with Christmas and Angelo in a 18-18 draw against Marist Old Boys
	+ Struck good form according to the Auckland Star

	+ Got through an immeasurable amount of good work in a heavy loss to Ponsonby
- June 1: Scored 2 tries in Kingsland's first win, 17 points to 5 over Ellerslie
	+ Outstanding and played sufficiently deeply to cooperate with Angelo and Nasey
	+ Second try was a gem, a solo effort in swerving brilliance

	+ Lacked opportunities but still played a great defensive game towards the end

- Player’s name is List
- Position: Wing/Center
- Played for Auckland and Kingsland Athletic
- 1929 season:
	+ Scored a try in Auckland's 22–19 win over Taranaki
	+ Chosen in the 22-man Auckland training squad for their match against Canterbury
	+ Played on the wing in Auckland’s 47-18 win over Canterbury
	+ Scored the home side's final try
	+ Failed to make the North Island side to play the South Island
	+ Played 14 matches for Kingsland Athletic and scored 7 tries for them
	+ Only played one match for Auckland out of their three matches
- 1930 season:
	+ Auckland Star said “List is a steady and resolute exponent with plenty of experience”
	+ Kingsland lost their opening game to Marist 16-13 but were awarded the victory
	+ List was involved in much of Kingsland's attacking work
	+ Selected in the 23-man training squad for Auckland's match with Northland
	+ Played for Kingsland against Newton on May 10 in a 14–8 loss
	+ Named on the wing for Auckland for their May 17 match with Northland
	+ Auckland won the match 21-16 before a crowd of 8,000 at Carlaw Park
	+ Had a rare poor game, dropped passes and uncertain in his movements
	+ Omitted from the Auckland side to play South Auckland on May 31
	+ Played the remainder of the season in the maroon jersey of Kingsland
	+ Scored a try in a 31–10 loss to Ellerslie
	+ Played well against City, “a tower of strength to his side”
	+ Scored a try against Devonport in a 13–6 loss
	+ Scored two tries in Kingsland's 13–5 win over Newton
	+ Played a strenuous and consistent all-round game against Ellerslie
	+ Scored a try and was involved with 2 others in a 1

- Played for Kingsland, then joined Marist after a merger in 1931
- Scored tries against Ponsonby, Marist, Devonport, Newton, Ellerslie, City Rovers, and Richmond Rovers
- Involved in 3 tries in a 18-16 loss to Ellerslie
- Scored 2 tries in Kingsland's 13-5 win over Newton
- Played a "strenuous and consistent all-round game" against Ellerslie
- Suggested to play back row forward for Marist
- Scored a try on debut for Marist in an 11-10 win over Richmond Rovers
- Scored tries against Ponsonby, Devonport, and Wellington combined clubs
- Helped Marist win the 1931 Fox Memorial championship
- Selected to play for North Island in inter-island match with South Island

Kingsland:
- Played against Ponsonby, Marist, and Devonport
- List scored a try in a 13-6 loss to Devonport
- List was "easily the best back" and "his fine defensive work prevented a heavier defeat"
- List "at centre, was brilliant in patches"
- List scored 2 tries in Kingsland's 13-5 win over Newton

Marist:
- List joined Marist with Kingsland merger in 1931
- Suggested as early favorites to win the competition due to strong back line and addition of Kingsland players
- List "is likely to play back row forward, a position to which he should easily accustom himself"
- Scored a try on debut for Marist in an 11-10 win over Richmond Rovers
- Scored tries against Ponsonby, Devonport, and Wellington combined clubs
- Helped Marist win the 1931 Fox Memorial championship
- List "is playing in good form at present and deserves a place in the three-quarter line" for North Island

Auckland Rugby League:
- Created a reserve grade competition in 1931
- Felt that the senior grade had too many teams and the competition was weaker than when it had 6
- Decided to force mer

- Marist won the 1931 Fox Memorial championship
- List scored tries in matches against Wellington Show Stadium, Ellerslie-Otahuhu Leopards/Otahuhu, and Devonport
- Selected for North Island in inter-island match against South Island
- Played as center and scored 3 tries, involved in 2 others, in North Island's 52-23 win
- Played against Devonport in Roope Rooster semi-finals, setting up both Marist tries in 11-8 loss
- Missed the Stormont Shield final due to injury
- Named to practice for Auckland's match against Northland but ultimately unavailable to play
- Missed the combined Marist-Devonport sides match against Eastern Suburbs from Sydney
- In 1932, scored 9 tries for Marist, the most of any player in Auckland
- Played in all 3 test matches for New Zealand against England
- Also played for Auckland, an Auckland XIII, and the North Island
- Marist finished runner-up in the Fox Memorial first grade championship
- Scored 2 tries against Ponsonby in the 4th round match
- Played brilliantly against City, displaying great speed and elusive side-step
- Vigorous straight running and clever moves against Ponsonby in a 25-21 loss.

- Brisbane, List, Davidson, and Seagar have been outstanding in tackling this season.
- List played most brilliantly at center in the first half against City, displaying great speed and elusive side-step.
- In a match against Ponsonby, List was the star of the rear divisions, with vigorous straight running and clever moves.
- He scored a try and was involved in two others, including a 50-yard run that led to a try by McDonald.
- List was named in the Auckland XIII team to play against South Auckland on July 16, and scored 3 tries in their 29–13 win.
- He was also named in the North Island side for the inter-island match, which they won 27-18 with List scoring a try.
- List was selected in the centres for the first test against England, but New Zealand was outclassed 24 points to 9.
- Despite the loss, List retained his place in the second test, and was selected to play for Auckland against the touring side on the wing.
- He played on the wing opposite Stanley Smith, and scored a try amid great excitement following a long kick by Cooke.
- List was the largest of the Auckland backs, with a weight of 12 stone and an average weight of 11st 3lb for the team.

- Auckland player, List, was the largest of the backs with an average weight of 11st 3lb, and played on the wing opposite Stanley Smith.
- Auckland played against England, losing the match 19-14 before a crowd of 15,000 at Carlaw Park on August 6.
- List was prominent in the game, with support from Brisbane, but was thrown into touch during a passing bout between Hassan and Davidson.
- During the second half, List raced down the sideline and scored a try amid great excitement, but failed to score another dangerous plunge for the line.
- List traveled with 10 other Aucklanders to Christchurch for the second test on August 13.
- Changes were made to the New Zealand back line, with List on the wing, Cooke and Brisbane in the center positions, Davidson on the other wing, Hassan at five eighth, and Abbott at halfback.
- List scored both of New Zealand's tries, but New Zealand lost the match 25-14 before 5,000 spectators.
- In the third test on August 30, List was named on the right wing, opposite Barney Hudson. New Zealand lost the final test 20-18 after leading 18-17 with a minute to go before 12,000 spectators.
- After the English tour, List returned to his Marist side to finish the season.
- List played in their semi-final win in the Roope Rooster over Devonport on September 3, scoring a try and his play along with Schultz was a feature of the match.
- Marist met City in the final and won comfortably 28-8, with List scoring a remarkable 4 tries.
- Marist then met Devonport in the Stormont Shield final on September 17, winning 15-8, with List scoring again.
- Marist traveled to New Plymouth to play Taranaki, going down 25-17.
- They then had a 37-8 win over Ponsonby in a Max Jaffe Cup charity match on October 8, with List scoring 2 tries and kicking 2 rare conversions.
- List's

- Marist won Stormont Shield final against Devonport on September 17, with List scoring again.
- Marist lost to Taranaki on October 3 and won against Ponsonby on October 8 in a charity match, with List scoring 2 tries and 2 conversions.
- List played 21 matches for Marist and 3 matches for Auckland in 1933, scoring a total of 7 tries and 1 conversion.
- At the age of 30, List played his final representative matches of his career, despite playing senior club football for a further 9 seasons.
- List was criticized for poor performance in a match against Ponsonby but improved in the following games.
- List was selected for Auckland’s first representative match of the season against Taranaki, despite losing form.
- Auckland won the match 32-20, with List playing his best game of the season, but was criticized for poor passes.
- List scored 3 tries and kicked a conversion in a match against Devonport on June 17, and 2 more tries in a win over Ponsonby.
- List was selected for Auckland's second match of the season against South Auckland on July 15, but they lost the match 14-0.
- List returned to the Marist side and scored a try in a win over Ponsonby on July 29.
- Marist finished runner-up in the championship to Devonport, and in the Challenge Cup competition to Newton.
- List missed selection for Auckland in matches against Taranaki, North Auckland, West Coast, and Hawke’s Bay.
- List was chosen in the reserves in Auckland's final match of the season against South Auckland on September 9, and came on to replace Bert Cooke and move to the wing.
- List missed a try and scored one for Auckland in their win against South Auckland.

- August 19, 1933: List, a quarterback for the Auckland football team, was praised for his performance in a match against Newton, despite missing several matches earlier in the season.
- September 9, 1933: List came on as a substitute for Bert Cooke in the match against South Auckland and scored a try, helping Auckland secure a 9-2 lead.
- List played in a curtain-raiser match for Marist against Devonport before the Auckland match, resulting in him playing over 3 halves of football.
- Marist played against the touring St. George side from Sydney, with List playing on the wing and marking Len Brennan. Marist won the match 25-11.
- List finished the season with a Max Jaffe Cup match against Richmond and an unemployed charity match.
- 1934: List transferred to Mount Albert United late in the season after falling out with Marist over financial issues.
- List only played 3 matches for Marist in 1934 and was suspended by the club due to a dispute over club finances.
- The Auckland Rugby League declared the suspensions "out of order," but the Marist club appealed to the New Zealand Rugby League, who upheld the suspensions.
- List was granted a transfer to Mount Albert United in August, along with several other suspended players.
- Mount Albert had been seeking senior grade status and were allowed to enter a team in the Roope Rooster competition.
- Mount Albert lost their Roope Rooster match against Ponsonby 19-11.

- Wilf Hassan had already left to join Marist rugby, while four players including List were suspended and later allowed to apply for a transfer.
- List did not play for months and eventually transferred to Mount Albert United in August.
- In the 1935 season, List played 15 games for Mount Albert, scoring 4 tries and 1 conversion.
- He started playing as a forward in the opening match against City and was mentioned for his tackling in the following week's game against Richmond.
- List scored his first points for Mount Albert in a 27-14 win over City Rovers on June 15.
- He was moved back to center and was involved in the only try of the match in a 3-0 win over Newton.
- List played fairly well at center against Devonport on July 13 and scored a try in a 18-6 win over Marist on July 20.
- He was forced into the forwards when Richard Shadbolt was injured and played well in the position against Ponsonby.
- Mount Albert lost the final match against Richmond 15-9, and List was said to have weak handling at times.
- In the Roope Rooster knockout competition, List was in an 18-15 win over Marist.
- In the 1936 season, List began playing a mixture of senior and senior reserve grade matches for Mount Albert.
- He played 8 senior games, scoring 2 tries, and began the season playing 2 games for their top side.
- List scored his only points of the season for the first grade side, 2 tries, in a 21-18 loss to City on June 6.

- In 1936, Claude List played 8 senior games for Mount Albert, scoring 2 tries. He began the season playing 2 games for their top side and was named in the first grade side in some weeks but not others.
- On May 30, he played against Manukau and scored his only points of the season, 2 tries.
- In 1937, List played the entire season in reserve grade.
- In 1938, he began the season in reserve grade and was named in the senior side to play Papakura on June 11, possibly his first game with his brother Francis.
- On June 18, Francis scored a try but Claude was not impressive on the wing.
- In a 10–8 win over Ponsonby, Claude was involved in his brother's try.
- Against Newton, he was involved in a try to Jack Tristram.
- In a 9–3 win over North Shore, List's all-round play on the wing was good.
- He then spent a few weeks in the reserves before playing for the senior side against City in a 28–13 win.
- In the final round of the competition, Mount Albert beat Papakura 44-12 but they needed a Marist loss to force a playoff for the championship.
- In 1939, List played the year in the reserve grade competition.
- In 1940, he spent the season entirely in the reserve grade.
- In 1941, List resumed his senior playing career for Mount Albert at the age of 39, playing 19 games and scoring 2 tries in his 17th season of senior football.
- List received a trophy for services rendered at the annual general meeting on February 20, 1939, while his brother Francis won the award for the most consistent forward.
- Claude also won the C. Elwin Memorial Cup for the annual 100 yards championship in 1939.

- In 1941, Claude List, a 39-year-old veteran player, returned to the senior football scene for Mount Albert after the reserve grade competition ceased due to the war.
- List played 19 games, scored 2 tries, and was a prominent figure in the forwards during the 1941 season.
- His performances were consistently noteworthy:
	1. Against Marist, he was "prominent" in a 20–18 loss.
	2. Against City, he played "well among the forwards" in an 11–10 win.
	3. In a 13–8 win over Richmond, he put in another "good game."
	4. Against Manukau, he showed resilience in a 14–5 loss.
	5. Against North Shore, he was described as a "hard toiler" in a 30–8 defeat.
	6. Against Ponsonby, he did "good work among the Mount Albert forwards" in a 10–6 loss.
	7. Against North Shore, he showed "good form" in a 16–13 win.
- List's career highlights include:
	1. 29 years of continuous football.
	2. Playing for the old Kingsland club in Auckland since 1921.
	3. Gaining both New Zealand and Auckland representative honors.
	4. First appearance for Auckland in 1927.
	5. Selected for the New Zealand team in 1928 while still a senior B grade player.
	6. Played all three tests for New Zealand against England in 1932.
	7. Played a remarkable game against England in Christchurch, standing out as the best back.
	8. Played football for a league team in Queensland as a schoolboy in 1912.
- In 1942, List's team, Mount Albert, was merged with Newton Rangers due to the reduction in senior players during the war.
- List made his season debut on June 6 in their round 4 match with Manukau.
- He played as a "prominent forward" in their 23–17 win

- Claude List played as a forward in rugby league
- He played for Mount Albert and was combined with Newton Rangers in 1942 due to a reduction in senior players during the war
- List did not play in the initial matches but made his season debut on June 6 against Manukau
- He was a "prominent forward" in wins against Richmond and City-Otahuhu
- List retired from rugby league after the 1942 season, having played for 30 seasons
- He was born in Australia and moved to New Zealand with his family, initially living in Glen Eden before moving to the inner city suburbs
- In 1928, List was living at 141 Newton Road, Auckland and working as a mechanic
- He married Iris (Margrey) Thornburn on March 25, 1931 at St. Matthew's Church in Auckland
- They had one son, Trevor Henry Wilchefski, born on December 29, 1932
- The family lived on Paget Street in Freemans Bay in the 1930s and Hepburn Street in Ponsonby in the 1940s
- In the late 1950s, they moved to Pollen Street in Ponsonby and then to Main Rd in Silverdale
- Claude List died on April 17, 1959, aged 56.
